constituent.sentence_1: The mayor's constituents are no longer happy with her performance and plan to vote for another candidate in the upcoming election.
constituent.sentence_2: The constituents of the metal alloy are nickel, copper, and tin.
constituent.meaning_2: noun: an abstract part of something
constituent.meaning_1: noun: a citizen who is represented in a government by officials for whom he or she votes

pedestrian.wordExtraNote: This word has other definitions but this is the most important one to study
pedestrian.sentence_1: While Nan was always engaged in philosophical speculation, her brother was occupied with far more pedestrian concerns: how to earn a salary and run a household.

arcane.meaning_1: adjective: requiring secret or mysterious knowledge
arcane.sentence_1: Most college fraternities are known for arcane rituals that those hoping to join the fraternity must learn.

sporadic.meaning_1: adjective: recurring in scattered and irregular or unpredictable instances
sporadic.sentence_1: The signals were at first sporadic, but now we detect a clear, consistent pattern of electromagnetic radiation emanating from deep space.

prolific.sentence_1: Schubert was the most prolific composer, producing hundreds of hours of music before he died at the age of 31.

gauche.sentence_1: Sylvester says the most gauche things, such as telling a girl he liked that she was much prettier when she wore makeup.

winsome.meaning_1: adjective: charming in a childlike or naive way
winsome.sentence_1: She was winsome by nature, and many people were drawn to this free and playful spirit.

poignant.sentence_1: After the Montagues and Capulets discover the dead bodies of Romeo and Juliet, in the play's most poignant moment, the two griefstricken families agree to end their feud once and for all.

sanction.sentence_1: The authorities have sanctioned the use of the wilderness reserve for public use; many expect to see hikers and campers enjoying the park in the coming months.
sanction.sentence_2: International sanctions have been placed on certain shipping lanes that were thought to be involved in human trafficking.
sanction.meaning_2: noun: a legal penalty for a forbidden action
sanction.meaning_1: verb: give authority or permission to

vacillate.wordExtraNote: This word has other definitions but this is the most important one to study
vacillate.meaning_1: verb: be undecided about something; waver between conflicting positions or courses of action
vacillate.sentence_1: Some students vacillate between schools when deciding which to attend, while others focus only on one school.

sycophant.meaning_1: noun: a person who tries to please someone in order to gain a personal advantage
sycophant.sentence_1: The CEO was unaware of the damaging consequences of his choices, largely because he surrounded himself with sycophants who would never dare criticize him.

reverent.meaning_1: adjective: feeling or showing profound respect or veneration
reverent.sentence_1: The professor could speak objectively about the other composers, but he always lectured about Brahms with a particularly reverent air, unable to offer a single criticism of his compositions.

tractable.meaning_1: adjective: readily reacting to suggestions and influences; easily managed (controlled or taught or molded)
tractable.sentence_1: Compared to middle school students, who have an untamed wildness about them, high school students are somewhat more tractable.

inscrutable.sentence_1: His speech was so dense and confusing that many in the audience found it inscrutable.

accolade.meaning_1: noun: an award or praise granted as a special honor
accolade.sentence_1: Jean Paul-Sartre was not a fan of accolades, and as such, he refused to accept the Nobel Prize for Literature in 1964.

brazen.meaning_1: adjective: unrestrained by convention or propriety
brazen.sentence_1: Their large "donations" to the local police department gave the drug cartel the brazen confidence to do their business out in the open.

circumscribe.wordExtraNote: This word has other definitions but this is the most important one to study
circumscribe.sentence_1: Their tour of South America was circumscribed so that they saw only popular destinations and avoided the dangerous parts of cities.

foment.meaning_1: verb: try to stir up public opinion
foment.sentence_1: After having his pay cut, Phil spread vicious rumors about his boss, hoping to foment a general feeling of discontent.

Magoosh Practice Questions.meaning_1: noun: Test your understanding of concepts from lesson videos. Learn more at http://gre.magoosh.com
Magoosh Practice Questions.sentence_1: Zach got 7/7 questions correct on a practice session using Magoosh practice questions.

admonish.meaning_1: verb: to warn strongly, even to the point of reprimanding
admonish.sentence_1: Before the concert began, security personnel admonished the crowd not to come up on stage during the performance.

garrulous.sentence_1: Lynne was garrulous: once, she had a fifteen minute conversation with a stranger before she realized the woman didn't speak English.

audacity.meaning_1: noun: aggressive boldness in social situations
audacity.sentence_1: Mike was upset at the man who not only cut in front of him at the ticket counter but also had the audacity to cut in front of him at the bathroom line.

inimical.meaning_1: adjective: hostile (usually describes conditions or environments)
inimical.sentence_1: Venus, with a surface temperature that would turn rubber to liquid, is inimical to any form of life.

intrepid.sentence_1: Captain Ahab was an intrepid captain whose reckless and fearless style ultimately lead to his downfall.

subversive.meaning_1: adjective: in opposition to an established system or institution.
subversive.sentence_1: The ruling political party has begun a campaign to shut down subversive websites that it deems as a threat to "national safety."

austere.sentence_2: Late Soviet architecture, although remaining largely austere, moved into experimental territory that employed previously unused shapes and structures.
austere.meaning_3: adjective: harsh in manner of temperament
austere.sentence_3: The principal of my elementary school was a cold, austere woman; I could never understand why she chose to work with children.
austere.meaning_2: adjective: unadorned in style or appearance
austere.sentence_1: His lifestyle of revelry and luxurious excess could hardly be called austere.

taciturn.sentence_1: While the CEO enthusiastically shares his plans and agenda with all who will listen, the CFO is far more taciturn, rarely revealing his perspective.

propitious.meaning_1: adjective: presenting favorable circumstances; likely to result in or show signs of success
propitious.sentence_1: The child's heartbeat is still weak, but I am seeing many propitious signs and I think that she may be healing.

obsequious.meaning_1: adjective: attentive in an ingratiating or servile manner; attempting to win favor from influential people by flattery
obsequious.sentence_1: The obsequious waiter did not give the couple a moment's peace all through the meal, constantly returning to their table to refill their water glasses and to tell them what a handsome pair they made.

irrevocable.meaning_1: adjective: incapable of being retracted or revoked
irrevocable.sentence_1: Once you enter your plea to the court, it is irrevocable so think carefully about what you will say.

repudiate.meaning_1: verb: reject as untrue or unfounded
repudiate.sentence_1: Many in the public believed the rumors of a UFO crash outside town, so the chief of police did everything he could to repudiate the rumors.

pernicious.meaning_1: adjective: exceedingly harmful; working or spreading in a hidden and injurious way
pernicious.sentence_1: The most successful viruses are pernicious: an infected person may feel perfectly healthy for several months while incubating and spreading the virus.

arbitrary.wordExtraNote: This word has other definitions but this is the most important one to study
arbitrary.meaning_1: adjective: based on a random, groundless decision
arbitrary.sentence_1: One of the arbitrary decrees in place during the emperor's rule is that all citizens pay him weekly homage at his palace.

myriad.sentence_1: There are a myriad of internet sites hawking pills that claim to boost energy for hours on end.

precipitous.meaning_1: adjective: done with very great haste and without due deliberation
precipitous.sentence_1: Instead of calling his financial advisor, Harold acted precipitously, buying 4,000 shares of the latest "hot" stock, only to find out that the company had a history of inflating its year end numbers.

ostracize.meaning_1: verb: exclude from a community or group
ostracize.sentence_1: Later in his life, Leo Tolstoy was ostracized from the Russian Orthodox Church for his writings that contradicted church doctrine.

tempered.sentence_1: The wide-eyed optimism of her youth was now tempered after she had worked many years in the criminal justice system.

lionize.meaning_1: verb: assign great social importance to
lionize.sentence_1: Students in the U.S. learn to lionize Jefferson, Franklin, and Washington because they are the founding fathers of the nation.

prodigious.meaning_1: adjective: so great in size or force or extent as to elicit awe
prodigious.sentence_1: After the relatively small homerun totals in the "dead ball" era, Babe Ruth's homerun totals were truly prodigious: every year, he set a new all-time record.

rescind.sentence_1: The man's driver's license was rescinded after his tenth car accident, which meant he would never be allowed to legally drive again.

scrupulous.sentence_1: Because of his scrupulous nature, Mary put him in charge of numbering and cataloging the entire collection of rare stamps.
scrupulous.sentence_2: Everyone trusted what he said and followed his example because he was scrupulous and honest.
scrupulous.meaning_2: adjective: having a sense of right and wrong; principled
scrupulous.meaning_1: adjective: characterized by extreme care and great effort

munificent.sentence_1: Uncle Charley was known for his munificence, giving all seven of his nephews lavish Christmas presents each year.

ravenous.meaning_1: adjective: extremely hungry; devouring or craving food in great quantities
ravenous.sentence_1: John didn't eat much at all during the week he had the flu, so now that he is regaining his health, it's not surprising that he has a ravenous appetite.

insolent.sentence_1: Lilian could not help herself from being insolent, commenting that the Queen's shoes were showing too much toe.

dilettante.meaning_1: noun: an amateur who engages in an activity without serious intentions and who pretends to have knowledge
dilettante.sentence_1: Fred has no formal medical training; while he likes to claim authority on medical issues, he is little more than a dilettante.

inveterate.sentence_1: He is an inveterate smoker and has told his family and friends that there is no way he will ever quit.

antithetical.meaning_1: adjective: sharply contrasted in character or purpose
antithetical.sentence_1: His deep emotional involvement with these ideas is, in fact, antithetical to the detachment Buddhism preaches.

resurgent.meaning_1: adjective: rising again as to new life and vigor
resurgent.sentence_1: The team sank to fourth place in June, but is now resurgent and about to win the division.

hegemony.meaning_1: noun: dominance over a certain area
hegemony.sentence_1: Until the Spanish Armada was defeated in 1587, Spain had hegemony over the seas, controlling waters stretching as far as the Americas.

trite.meaning_1: adjective: repeated too often; overfamiliar through overuse
trite.sentence_1: Many style guides recommend not using idioms in writing because these trite expressions are uninteresting and show a lack of imagination on the part of the writer.

haphazard.meaning_1: adjective: marked by great carelessness; dependent upon or characterized by chance
haphazard.sentence_1: Many golf courses are designed with great care, but the greens on the county golf course seem entirely haphazard.
